questions.question_text: Which of the following identity access methods creates a cookie on the first login to a central authority to allow logins to subsequent applications without re- entering credentials?

discussion.content: Key is here "Central Authority". Good luck guys!

comments.content: I didn't realize that but whenever I see that you don't have to re-enter your credentials I think SSO

discussion.content:
Single Sign-On (SSO) allows users to authenticate once and access multiple resources without being prompted for additional credentials. Okta supports both session and persistent SSO.

Session SSO: Session SSO cookies are written for the authenticated user, which eliminates further prompts when the user switches applications during a particular session. However, if a particular session ends, the user is prompted for their credentials again.

choices.A: Implementing a site-to-site VPN for server access.
choices.B: Implementing a DMZ segment for the server.
choices.C: Implementing NAT addressing for the servers.
choices.D: Implementing a sandbox to contain the servers.

discussion.content: The end goal of a DMZ is to allow an organization to access untrusted networks, such as the internet, while ensuring its private network or LAN remains secure. Organizations typically store external-facing services and resources, as well as servers for the Domain Name System (DNS), File Transfer Protocol (FTP), mail, proxy, Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP), and web servers, in the DMZ.
DMZ-- key word securing internal network

questions.question_text: A network technician is designing a network for a small company. The network technician needs to implement an email server and web server that will be accessed by both internal employees and external customers. Which of the following would BEST secure the internal network and allow access to the needed servers?

discussion.content: Something you have and something you know is the answer.

Something you have (Smart card)
Something you know (PIN)
2FA

questions.question_text: When used together, which of the following qualify as two-factor authentication?

discussion.content:
Ransomware is not a virus. It is malware that employs encryption to hold a victim's information at ransom and can be known to use the .pgp (pretty good privacy) encryption extension.
https://malwaretips.com/blogs/remove-pgp/

comments.content: Thanks! That's what I was thinking too.

discussion.content: File extension .pgp is for Pretty Good Privacy which is an encryption system. This how ramsomware works. It encrypts files and then demands payment to get a decryption key.
I'm so confused I don't know what to believe anymore. This site says D another site says A. This is so frustrating.

comments.content: It is not crypto or ransomware because we have not been told that files are encrypted and a ransom money is asked to unlock the file

discussion.content:
The question is asking us to differentiate between Malware and Virus. Malware is the superset meaning all type of malicious code written to corupt the normal operation is malware related. However, virus is the child of malware that need user's activity either to click or download the attachment . Virus never run on its own ,but worms can propagate (reproduce it self) with out any assistance. So the question is telling us that user Ann has taken some action by clicking the attachment so we are talking about computer virus
Answer D
D should be the answer since the data or Ann's computer was not yet compromised/encrypted.
A should be the answer. the malware is interacting with files that looks like important.

comments.content: Exploitation framework would be like metasploit. You are trying to find out more about the content which are hashed passwords. Password cracker is the simple answer to this simple question.
I would go with provided answer...

discussion.content: I would go with A an exploitation frame contains many tools useful to a pentester and may even contain a password cracker
oh I think I got it. the tool is required to crack the hash-- which is hash of the password.

questions.question_text: A company has a team of penetration testers. This team has located a file on the company file server that they believe contains cleartext usernames followed by a hash. Which of the following tools should the penetration testers use to learn more about the content of this file?
